review.title: Octopus: A Framework for Cost-Quality-Time Optimization in Crowdsourcing
review.abstract: Managing micro-tasks on crowdsourcing marketplaces involves balancing conflicting objectives -- the quality of work, total cost incurred and time to completion. Previous agents have focused on cost-quality, or cost-time tradeoffs, limiting their real-world applicability. As a step towards this goal we present Octopus, the first AI agent that jointly manages all three objectives in tandem. Octopus is based on a computationally tractable, multi-agent formulation consisting of three components; one that sets the price per ballot to adjust the rate of completion of tasks, another that optimizes each task for quality and a third that performs task selection. We demonstrate that Octopus outperforms existing state-of-the-art approaches in simulation and experiments with real data, demonstrating its superior performance. We also deploy Octopus on Amazon Mechanical Turk to establish its ability to manage tasks in a real-world, dynamic setting.

metadata.title: Octopus: A Framework for Cost-Quality-Time Optimization in Crowdsourcing

sections.text: In fact, most people who stand up for people's rights are able to decide for themselves what they want and what they don't want.

sections.heading: Related Work
sections.text: One branch of this research focuses on collective classification, which develops aggregation mechanisms to derive the best performance per task in the face of a static set of ballots (Whitehill et al. 2009; Welinder et al. 2010; Oleson et al. 2013; Parameswaran et al. 2012; Kamar et al. 2013), multi-label tasks (Bragg, Maud 2013), and tasks that go beyond multiple-choice answers (Lin, Mausam, and Weld 2012; Dai, Mausam, and Weld 2011), all of which work design agents to accept uniform pay.

sections.heading: Problem Definition
sections.text: An applicant provides a set of n binary tasks. < n > each problem with a 0 / 1 factor. They also provide a utility function that describes how to weigh costs, time and quality against each other. < n > The agent can dynamically change the payment per ballot c and select a variable number of ballots per ballot to optimize the final goal. We assume that the answers to all tasks are expressed to the applicant as a sum of tasks at task level (U) minus costs. An MDP / POMDP model models the long-term reward problem in full observability and is followed by a fivefold < S, T, R, Q >. We assume that answers to all tasks must be returned to the applicant as a single batch.

sections.heading: OCTOPUS for Three-Way Optimization
sections.text: We propose a three-component architecture (see Figure 1). In the OCTOPUS, each task has its own QUALITY MANAGER, which decides on the basis of the current payment whether it is worthwhile to do another round of voting (light edge) or not (dark edge) for this task. This information is forwarded to the TASKSELECTOR, which selects an available (light) task in order to get to an incoming worker. Based on the current progress of the entire batch, the COSTSETTER decides which payment is to be determined per ballot; this action is carried out at regular intervals. We design OCTOPUS so that it can assign tasks in such a way as and when workers arrive and work immediately in practice, so that it can use crowdsourced marketplaces with full parallelism.

sections.heading: TaskSelector
sections.text: The TASKSELECTOR decides which incomplete task is to be assigned to the next incoming worker. It must behave "at any time," i.e. it must quickly increase the benefit U, because the timing of the final submission is not in its control and the batch is at any time by COSTSETTER.To be prepared for contingencies, the TASKSELECTOR uses a one-step, greedy policy over the expected benefit. We define the priority of each task as the difference between the current benefit (Uq) of q and the expected benefit after obtaining 1 ballot (U ′ q) from an average worker (error rate), given the current belief that bq is the QUALITY MANAGER's QUALITY MANAGER.Therefore, QUq = E [U ′ q | q] of q | q] − Uq could be possible. The TASKSELECTOR assigns the task with the maximum benefit of q to the next available worker. Unfortunately, Uq (and therefore, neither a year of labor allocation) is neither a uniform nor a full one.

sections.heading: CostSetter
sections.text: The COSTSETTER is an MDP based on pay per ballot to maximize it. It uses information about the completion of each task to assess whether the number of tasks is being performed on schedule or whether it needs to be accelerated or slowed down. To influence the speed of completion of the batch, it relies c on discrete time steps, but that would make calculations unsustainable. Instead, we approach by using aggregated statistics on the entire batch of tasks. We describe the state space, the measures, the transitional functions and the rewards of this MDP below.The choice of the best pay per ballot c depends on its current value, and the current degree of completion of the batch.

sections.heading: Experiments
sections.text: We perform three sets of experiments: (i) experiments on simulated data; (ii) offline evaluation on real data; (iii) live experiments on Amazon MTurk (AMT). Model parameters. For experiments, we initialize OCTOPUS with a hard deadline function: Uq = − ∞ if they are independent; otherwise, Uq = − P for each erroneous answer and zero for a correct answer. This common utility combines the utilities of Dai et al.'s and Gao et al.' s models here, Penalty P represents how important quality is to the requester. Notice that since a POMDP does not know if it is submitting the correct answer, it does not use its belief to estimate the expected power exactly as − P (1 − vq). This linear utility makes the reward calculations for COSTSETTER simple.

sections.heading: Offline Experiments on Real Data
sections.text: We conduct extensive offline experiments with our collected data against the fundamentals described in the study. When comparing algorithms, we capture different execution paths from the real data by selecting a random ballot for each task (since quality is cost-free), while using an uninformed uniform distribution for the difficulty before the election.

sections.heading: Live Online Experiments
sections.text: In this case, there are exactly 3 HITS (of 10 tasks each) at once. If one worker accepts one HIT, another is immediately posted - this allows the processing of tasks calculated from real data. In this case, all available HITs are dismantled and re-booked with the new price performance of OCTOPUS. OCTOPUS policy is learned based on task fulfillment rates calculated from real data. In this case, OCTOPUS becomes instantaneous. We solve a batch of 500 tweets for 3 periods - 1, 2 and 4 hours.

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text: In this work, we focused on experiments with OCTOPUS within a set timeframe that can be compared with previous work. Extending to the popular fixed budget setting (where ∑ q Cq is limited) is simple: (i) Never synchronize θ so that its value in any state is simply the starting value of θ (which is fixed and known) minus the ballots received, making it a substitute for the costs incurred to date; (ii) Modify the COSTSETTER's reward to give a reward for the total costs (which can now be calculated on the basis of θ) that exceed the budget. Another extension involves the use of a different wording of the QUALITY MANAGER; any algorithm that defines an appropriate policy and from which we can calculate θ and ν is suitable.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: We present OCTOPUS, one of the first AI agents for a triple optimization of total cost, quality of work and completion time in crowdsourcing. The agent combines three different subagents that control quality per task, select the best next task, and determine payment for the entire batch. An essential technical contribution is the calculation of the overall statistics of quality and completeness of the entire batch - this is used as the state for the best determination of the next payment.OCTOPUS exceeds state-of-the-art baseline in a variety of simulated and real scenarios and demonstrates the superiority of our approach. We also demonstrate the applicability of OCTOPUS in the real world by using it directly on AMT. In the future, we hope to develop general formulations of OCTOPUS as a plug-and-play architecture for users.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This work is supported by Google Language Understanding and Knowledge Research Fellowships, a Bloomberg Prize, Microsoft Azure Sponsorship, and a Faculty Award from the Indian Government to the third author. We thank Chris Lin, Yihan Gao, and Aditya Parameswaran for sharing the code and all AMT staff who participated in our experiments.

metadata.abstractText: We present OCTOPUS, an AI agent to jointly balance three conflicting task objectives on a micro-crowdsourcing marketplace – the quality of work, total cost incurred, and time to completion. Previous control agents have mostly focused on cost-quality, or cost-time tradeoffs, but not on directly controlling all three in concert. A naive formulation of threeobjective optimization is intractable; OCTOPUS takes a hierarchical POMDP approach, with three different components responsible for setting the pay per task, selecting the next task, and controlling task-level quality. We demonstrate that OCTOPUS significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art approaches on real experiments. We also deploy OCTOPUS on Amazon Mechanical Turk, showing its ability to manage tasks in a real-world, dynamic setting.
